content:
In 115* there is no 'Mail Toolbar'. I has been replaced by the 'Unified Toolbar'. The 'Unified Toolbar' automatically has the Global Search and on far right the menu app icon. It can be Customised. Good info here: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/unified-toolbar

The 'Menu Bar' which has File Edit View is still available. Click on the Menu app icon (3 lines) 'View' > 'Toolbars' > select 'Menu Bar'
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Pressing F5 retrieves from highlighted account, or click File>Get New Messages for> account name

content:
Requested info above. Additional update:

I randomly tried putting emails on my webmail (Yahoo Mail for ATT) into a backup folder instead of inbox. Then I put just a few of those emails back into the inbox, opened Thunderbird, and they downloaded. I did the same thing, moving small numbers of the emails from the backup folder to inbox on Yahoo Mail, then re-opening Thunderbird, several times. I was able to download mail. But what a pain!! And I don't understand why this happened.

content: Please post your Troubleshooting Information. At the top right of the Thunderbird window, click the menu button ≡, then select Help > More Troubleshooting Information. Press the "Copy text to clipboard button" and paste the information into your reply.
creator: christ1

content: You can move messages off of the server to your 'Local Folders' account. This is a manual action though.
creator: christ1

content:
As in all my useful question & answers, I provide full instructions, so if you have already created a 'chrome' folder and 'userChrome.css' file then you may only need to copy the code.

This is the code I used. You can modify the colours to be whatever you desire. You may find this link useful for colour selection: https://www.w3schools.com/colors/colors_mixer.asp

Please check in Thunderbird to see if a setting needs switching on.

  • Settings > General
  • Scroll to bottom and click on 'Config Editor' button
  • In search type : legacy
  • look for this line: toolkit.legacyUserProfileCustomizations.stylesheets
  • If it is set as 'false' :
  • click on the far right arrow type icon to toggle from 'false' to say 'TRUE'

Now Do this: In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • in 'Application Basics' - Profile Folders - click on 'Open Folder'

A new window opens showing the contents of your profile name folder.

  • Exit Thunderbird now. This is important.

I'm going to give the full instructions because I do not know if people already know how to create and use a userChrome.css file.

  • In the 'profile name ' folder create a new folder and call it 'chrome'. The spelling is important - note it is all lower case.
  • Then open a simple text editor program such as 'Notepad'.
  • Copy all the text between the lines below and paste it into 'Notepad'. 
@import url("chrome://messenger/content/unifiedtoolbar/unifiedToolbarWebextensions.css"); @namespace html url("http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml");  /* Position Menu Bar above Unified Toolbar and change colour */ #toolbar-menubar { order: -1 !important; background-color: #002633 !important;  /* Color of menu bar             */ color:            white !important;  /* Color of the text - if needed */ }   /* Tabmail Tab */  /*Remove the theme override */ .tabmail-tab .tab-background[selected=true]:-moz-lwtheme {   background-image: none !important; } /*Change selected tab colour to match title bar - seafoam teal is #008083 */ .tab-background[selected=true] {   background-color:  #008083 !important;   background-repeat: repeat-x; } /*Change colour of the blue top line on selected tab - */ .tab-line[selected=true] {   background-color: #002633 !important;  } /*not selected tab same as menu bar colour #002633*/ .tab-background:not([selected=true]) {   background-color:#002633 !important;  } /* hover on none selected tab force line to seafoam teal #008083 */ .tabmail-tab:hover .tab-line:not([selected=true]) {   background-color:  #008083 !important;  }
  • Save the file as 'userChrome.css' - note the spelling of this is important - all lower case except the C.
  • Save it in the 'chrome' folder. - see attached image as guide.

Check that file really is called 'userChrome.css' and not 'userChrome.css.txt' - it has to be saved as a Cascading Style Sheet (css) and not a text document. So if you see 'userChrome.css.txt' - no problem - just rename it by removing the .txt - you will get ask are you sure as it may effect things - just say yes because you really do want to do it.

Start Thunderbird
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
I enabled the title bar and it took the colour of my Windows theme. I enabled the Menu Bar and then moved it up above the Unified Toolbar: See info at this link : https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1422908

I wanted my Menu Bar to have a complimentary colour to the titlebar. I also wanted the same colour for non selected tabs. In addition, I wanted the selected tab to have same colour as Titlebar and the hover over tab to pick up a line colour of a selected tab.

Now it looks like the image shown below.

content:
Sadly, that didn't work. This may give you an idea of the magnitude of the problem is. Here are some screenshots that show how many emails are marked as unread and where they are located. So far I've only found two ways to get the messages marked as read. 1) The easiest way is to select an individual folder then Right-Click and select Mark Fold Read. 2) Left click on the folder, then hit Cont/A and then M.

However, it sure would be nice if there was a way to mark all of the emails in all of my folders as read without having to do it one folder at a time.

BTW, thank you very much for at least trying to help!!!
creator: tuttleja

content: That's why I said "Right-click the top folder". I haven't tried this though.
creator: christ1

content: Maybe I wasn't clear enough. IN the screenshot you see the folder Player_A-J, and at the time I took the screenshot, there were 4955 unread emails. Now there are 13163 -and counting. You see, Player_A-J is the main folder, and inside that folder are dozens of sub-folders, and inside those sub-folder are the individual folders of dozens of customers. The unread emails are scattered throughout literally thousands of customer folders (approximately 9000). Here's just one example of a partial list of customers with the first name David, and this is just for DavidD-Debra. Right now, the only way to get the messages Read is to right-click and select Mark Folder Read. It could take weeks, if not longer, to do that.
creator: tuttleja

content:
Is there some trick to bulk Read all those emails without opening each of the 9000+ folders?

Right-click the top folder with unread messages in the folder pane - Mark Folder Read

I migrated all of my 80000+ emails from a previous version of Thunderbird to Supernova.

Not sure what that means. You just need to update the application. There is nothing you need to actively "migrate" in the profile.

content:
I solved the problem!!! In the screenshot, just below the ImapMail folder is the Mail folder. HOWEVER, that's not the way the directory looked ten minutes ago. Ten minutes ago, there was another Mail folder and it had the Local Folder under it. BUT, just below the Local Folder (in the tree) was the Mail folder you see in the screenshot. AND, it had all of my 20+ gigs of mail folders. So, I simply dragged that Mail folder to the 'oiwuy5s.default-release' folder. When I did that, the computer asked if I wanted to merge the files, and I said YES. Then when I opened Thunderbird again, all of my mail folders (over 9000) were there. (There was lots of other Local Folders and Imported folders, but I deleted all of them until all I had left were the right ones.

Now the only thing I'm wondering is, Can I get rid of some of those 'smart mailboxes'? I'm guessing there's only suppose to be ONE.
creator: tuttleja

creator: clwickers

content:
Is this a Pop or Imap mail account ?

If Imap then it's possible the 'Deleted Messages' is actually the name of the 'Trash' folder provided by the server. First: Find out which folder is being used by the server. Logon to webmail account via a browser. Delete an email and notice which webmail folder now has the deleted email. In webmail account did the deleted email auto get put in 'Deleted Messages' or 'Deleted' ?

Now test sending an email in webmail account. Which folder did the sent message get auto put into in the webmail account? Was it 'Sent' or 'Sent Messages' ?

We have to know which folder is your default folders - the one the server uses - then we can sort out what needs to kept in the imap account and which folder you need to have selected in Account Settings > Copies & Folders.
creator: Toad-Hall

there is a contact form for issues and questions about donations. It is not a topic for this Support forum where you are interacting with fellow users for support.

If you issue is not covered in the FAQ which is linked from the doanations page you might try using the contact link https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/donate/help/

Personally I think your question as stated is fully answered in the FAQ.

Why do you need my address in order to process a gift? We understand that your privacy is very important. We ask for a minimum amount of information required to process credit card payments, including billing addresses. This allows our payment processor to verify your identity, process your payment, and prevent fraudulent charges to your credit card. We keep your information private — if you have questions, please refer to our Privacy Policy. If you would rather not fill in your information on our online form, you can mail us a check.

content:
THanks Matt.

your reply set me on the right path - I went to the "View" menu, and found that the "Density" sub-menu choice had been switched to "Compact" when I downloaded the new version (115.3)

Checking, instead, "Default" made the message list more readable, and increasing the Font size, as you noted, also helped
creator: gfwtgfwt

content:
If you were talking about a dozen eggs and you got 5 broken ones and the seller refused to help with that I would agree with you. Despite popular ideas to the contrary computers remain highly technical tools and are not even now in the same category as an old DVD player that you can expect to "just work". Despite the fact they often did not with the new Disney releases. Interestingly the advances in monitor sizes and hence the size of pixels (which is the basis of Thunderbird scaling) means that occasionally the software gets it wrong. This is not really to be unexpected when it required a cooperative interaction between Thunderbird, the operating system and a video driver usually written by the video card manufacturer to work flawlessly.

I am guessing you got an update and your font is apparently smaller. Where I do not know, because you forgot to mention that part, so I will guess it is in the message lists and folder names.

Go to the View menu (in V102). Click on the plus sign on that menu Go to the menu and click on the plus sign beside the word Font (in V115)
creator: MattAuSupport
